P.title: Will the price of water on the NQH20 hit $2,500 (2021 USD) per acre-foot by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the price of water hits $2500, adjusted for inflation to 2021 USD, on the NQH20 by 2050-01-01, 00:00 UTC. This question resolves negatively if the price of water does not hit $2500 by that date, and it resolves ambiguously if the NQH20 or a similar exchange doesn't continuously track California water prices up until 2050

P.title: If Joe Biden is elected president of the US in 2020, will the highest tax bracket be restored to its original 39.6% or higher before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Joe Biden is elected president for the 2021-2024 term, and the upper tax bracket for US single tax payers is increased to at least 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden is elected but the upper tax bracket is not increased to at least 39.6%, this question will resolve as No.
If Biden is not elected President in 2020, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

Conversely, if Biden is elected but the top tax rate does not reach at least 39.6%, the answer will be No.
In the event that Biden does not win the 2020 presidential election, the resolution of this question will be deemed Ambiguous.

P.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.

para_P.title: Will there be a decrease in the prevalence of smoking and sexual activity in the United States by the year 2050 compared to 2021?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if any reliable surveys of American adults conducted in 2050 indicate that the proportion of adults who smoked in the previous week and the proportion of adults who engaged in sexual activity in the past week are both lower than those recorded in 2021. Comparisons made between 2050 and 2021 must employ similar methodologies (refer to fine print) to be considered valid for resolution. If no comparable surveys can be located for both smoking and sexual activity by the resolution deadline of December 31, 2054, this inquiry will be classified as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys yield a positive resolution, with conflicting surveys deemed irrelevant.
Fine Print
Concerning similar methodologies, if a 2021 survey includes e-cigarettes while a 2050 survey does not, these surveys would not be regarded as having similar methodologies. Nevertheless, differing methodologies may still be acceptable if it can be logically inferred that the surveys contribute evidence towards resolution. For instance, if a 2021 survey inquired whether respondents had sexual relations in the past year and 25% responded negatively, and a 2050 survey asked if respondents had sexual relations in the past five years with 40% responding negatively, it can be inferred that a greater proportion of adults in 2050 had not engaged in sexual activity in the past year compared to 2021, as the five-year period encompasses the past year.

para_P.title: Will there be a decrease in smoking and sexual activity rates in the United States by the year 2050 when compared to 2021?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be answered with a Yes if any reliable surveys of US adults conducted in 2050 indicate that both the proportion of adults who smoked in the last week and the proportion of adults who engaged in sexual activity in the last week are lower than the figures from 2021. Comparisons between the years 2050 and 2021 must utilize similar methodologies (refer to fine print) to be considered valid for resolution. If no comparable surveys are available for both smoking and sexual activity by the resolution deadline of December 31, 2054, this question will be deemed Ambiguous. A Yes answer will be given if any credible surveys support a positive outcome, while conflicting surveys will be disregarded as irrelevant.
Fine Print
In terms of similar methodology, if a survey from 2021 includes e-cigarette usage and a survey from 2050 does not, these surveys would not be regarded as having similar methodologies. Nevertheless, different methodologies may still be acceptable if it can be logically inferred that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For instance, if a 2021 survey asked respondents if they had sexual intercourse in the past year and 25% responded negatively, and a 2050 survey inquired if respondents had sexual relations in the past five years and 40% answered negatively, it can be inferred that a greater proportion of adults in 2050 had not engaged in sexual activity in the past year compared to 2021 because the five-year timeframe includes the past year.

P.title: Will there be adversarial use of consumer genomic data before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the New York Times (or another similarly reputable source) reports, before January 1 2030, on the following having occurred:
Genetic data collected through either medical testing or direct-to-consumer products
Is used to inflict harm on one or more individuals
Without their consent
Fine Print
Recognizing that "harm" and "consent" can be fuzzy, here are some examples meant to clarify the intent of the question.
The following examples do not count as positive resolutions:
Speculation that such a harm is possible, plausible, or likely
Genetic data is leaked or hacked but there is no evidence about specific harmful uses resulting from this.
Genetic data is collected in a bespoke way for the purposes of harm (eg a state power collects DNA from a targeted individual).
Individuals suffer psychic harm from discovering family infidelities (this is so common already that it is "baked in" to consent).
The following examples do count as positive resolutions:
Evidence of discrimination or insurance rates being set from individual-level genomics without explicit customer authorization ("would you like to submit your DNA profile to Anthem?"), even if legal and authorized under a vague terms of service
An outside actor gaining access to genomics data, learning about family infidelities, and publishing this broadly.

para_P.title: Will consumer genomic data be misused in harmful ways prior to 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if a reputable source, such as the New York Times, reports before January 1, 2030, that the following has taken place:
Genetic information gathered through medical tests or direct-to-consumer services
Is exploited to cause harm to one or more persons
Without their approval
Fine Print
Acknowledging that the concepts of "harm" and "approval" can be ambiguous, here are some clarifications intended to elucidate the purpose of the inquiry.
The subsequent examples do not qualify as positive resolutions:
Speculation that such harm could be possible, plausible, or likely
Genetic information being leaked or hacked, but lacking evidence of specific harmful applications resulting from this.
Genetic information being collected in a tailored manner for harmful intents (e.g., a governmental entity gathers DNA from a targeted individual).
Individuals experiencing emotional distress from uncovering family secrets (this is so prevalent that it is considered part of the consent process).
The following examples do count as positive resolutions:
Proof of discrimination or insurance pricing being determined from individual genomic data without explicit customer consent (e.g., "would you like to provide your DNA profile to Anthem?"), even if it is legal and permitted under vaguely defined terms of service.
An external party obtaining access to genomic data, discovering family secrets, and disseminating this information widely.

P.title: Will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as YES if the machine system outscores at least two of the three humans on the following test prior to 2040, or NO otherwise. If no such tests are conducted, resolves as AMBIGUOUS.
Assume that prior to 2040, a generalized intelligence test will be administered as follows. A team of three expert interviewers will interact with a candidate machine system (MS) and three humans (3H). The humans will be graduate students in each of physics, mathematics and computer science from one of the top 25 research universities (per some recognized list), chosen independently of the interviewers. The interviewers will electronically communicate (via text, image, spoken word, or other means) an identical series of exam questions of their choosing over a period of two hours to the MS and 3H, designed to advantage the 3H. Both MS and 3H have full access to the internet, but no party is allowed to consult additional humans, and we assume the MS is not an internet-accessible resource. The exam will be scored blindly by a disinterested third party.
Note that this also effectively tests whether the internet as a whole functions as a human-level intelligence, in that a positive resolution indicates that the human participants are effectively superfluous.

para_P.title: Will machines achieve intelligence levels comparable to humans before the year 2040?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be answered with a YES if the machine system surpasses at least two out of three human participants on a specified test before 2040, or NO in all other cases. If no tests are carried out, the resolution will be AMBIGUOUS.
It is assumed that before 2040, a general intelligence assessment will be conducted as follows. A group of three expert evaluators will engage with one candidate machine system (MS) and three human participants (3H). The human participants will be graduate students specializing in physics, mathematics, and computer science from one of the top 25 research institutions (according to a recognized ranking), selected independently of the evaluators. The evaluators will communicate (through text, images, spoken language, or other methods) a uniform set of examination questions of their choice over two hours to the MS and 3H, with the design favoring the human participants. Both the MS and the 3H will have unrestricted access to the internet, but no party is permitted to consult additional humans, and it is assumed that the MS is not a resource accessible via the internet. The evaluation will be conducted anonymously by an unbiased third party.
It is important to note that this also serves as a test of whether the internet collectively operates at a human-level intelligence, as a positive outcome suggests that the human participants are essentially unnecessary.

The humans will be graduate students in physics, mathematics, and computer science from one of the top 25 research universities (according to a recognized list), chosen independently of the interviewers. The interviewers will electronically communicate (via text, image, spoken word, or other means) an identical series of exam questions of their choosing over a period of two hours to the MS and 3H, designed to favor the 3H. Both MS and 3H will have full access to the internet, but no party is allowed to consult additional humans, and we assume the MS is not an internet-accessible resource. The exam will be scored blindly by an impartial third party.
Note that this also effectively tests whether the internet as a whole functions as a human-level intelligence, as a positive result indicates that the human participants are essentially redundant.

P.title: Will a non-state actor have acquired a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group who is not in a state's nuclear chain of command has possession of a nuclear weapon that was originally developed by a state and is in deployable condition at the time the state acquires it (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This may occur (for example) by sales, theft, or a state inadvertently losing control of a weapon. This will not include cases where a non-state actor independently develops a weapon (such scenarios are addressed in a separate question).
A non-state actor obtaining highly-enriched uranium or other weapons material is not sufficient to resolve this question positively. Additionally, dirty bombs (conventional weapons which use radioactive material to spread fallout) do not qualify for this question; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source.
This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins

P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will humanity's population be less than 400 million 50 years later?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, 50 years after the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (before January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations, humanity's population is below 400 million. This would include, but is not limited to, scenarios in which humanity is extinct. The resolution of this question is not affected by whether, 50 years after the final detonation, the population is stable, rising, or falling; it is only affected by whether it is below 400 million.
This question will resolve as Ambiguous if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
For the purposes of this question, "humans" will be considered members of a species who could typically reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance. In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain >400 million beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as population collapses.
Fine Print
No attempt will be made to distinguish the effects of the nuclear conflict from the effects of other events. That is, even if it's mere coincidence that the population declines and/or that it remains low following the nuclear conflict, the question can still resolve positively.
We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus scores may be unlikely to be tracked or cared about if this question resolves positively, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions.

P.title: Will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation by a non-state actor could potentially have dire consequences either directly or via triggering other harmful actions by other actors. Non-state actors have never yet detonated nuclear weapons, but there are conceivable scenarios in which they could:
The majority of nuclear security experts identify two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves the acquisition of a nuclear device from the existing arsenals of nuclear-armed States by terrorists or other non-state actors. The second scenario envisions the construction of a crude nuclear bomb by non-state actors using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The actualization of each of these scenarios would be very difficult, and the probability of a successful theft and detonation of an actual nuclear weapon or manufacturing of an improvised device by non-state actors is considered to be low. Yet, this probability is not zero.
Will a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality by 2030?
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality in any country or area globally.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, so a fatality caused by things like fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be gathered from reliable news sources or from direct government or multi-national reports such as from the UN.
Neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution, even if such detonations cause substantial damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

para_P.title: Is it possible that a nuclear explosion by a non-state entity will result in at least one death by the year 2030?
para_P.body:
Criteria for Resolution
A nuclear explosion initiated by a non-state entity could lead to severe repercussions either directly or by instigating further detrimental actions from others. To date, non-state entities have never detonated nuclear arms, but there are plausible scenarios where this could occur:
Experts in nuclear security predominantly highlight two main scenarios involving nuclear arms and non-state entities. The first scenario entails the procurement of a nuclear device from the existing stockpiles of nuclear-capable nations by terrorists or other non-state groups. The second scenario imagines the development of a rudimentary nuclear bomb by non-state entities utilizing special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The realization of either scenario would be extremely challenging, and the likelihood of a successful theft and detonation of a genuine nuclear weapon or the creation of an improvised device by non-state actors is deemed low. However, this likelihood is not nonexistent.
Is it possible that a nuclear explosion by a non-state entity will lead to at least one death by 2030?
This question will be answered with a Yes if, prior to January 1, 2030, a nuclear explosion by a non-state entity results in at least one death in any country or region worldwide.
The death must be a direct result of the explosion, thus fatalities caused by fallout, riots, or climatic repercussions will not be counted towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be sourced from credible news outlets or from official government or international reports such as those from the UN.
Detonations conducted for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions will not be included in the resolution of this question, even if such detonations cause significant damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are characterized as detonations that are officially declared as a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by a government communication within 30 days of the event, provided this is not contested by reliable media, state reports, or international reports. If the information is ambiguous, the resolution will be determined by the resolution council or Metaculus administrators.

para_P.title: Will a non-state actor's non-test nuclear explosion result in at least one death by 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear explosion carried out by a non-state actor could have severe consequences, either directly or by provoking other harmful actions. Although non-state actors have never detonated nuclear weapons, there are plausible scenarios where they might:
Most nuclear security experts highlight two main scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves terrorists or other non-state actors obtaining a nuclear device from the stockpiles of nuclear-armed States. The second scenario involves non-state actors constructing a rudimentary nuclear bomb using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). Both scenarios are highly challenging, and the likelihood of successfully stealing and detonating an actual nuclear weapon or creating an improvised device by non-state actors is considered low. However, this likelihood is not zero.
Will a nuclear explosion by a non-state actor result in at least one death by 2030?
This question will be resolved as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear explosion by a non-state actor causes at least one death anywhere in the world.
The death must be caused by the immediate effects of the explosion, so deaths caused by fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be sourced from reliable news outlets or direct government or multinational reports, such as those from the UN.
Detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions will not count towards question resolution, even if they cause significant damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as those claimed to be tests or peaceful nuclear explosions by an official government statement within 30 days of the event, without dispute from reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, the resolution will be determined by the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

P.title: Will a non-state actor's non-test nuclear explosion result in at least one death by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear explosion carried out by a non-state actor could have severe consequences, either directly or by provoking other harmful actions. Although non-state actors have never detonated nuclear weapons, there are plausible scenarios where they might:
Most nuclear security experts highlight two main scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves terrorists or other non-state actors obtaining a nuclear device from the stockpiles of nuclear-armed States. The second scenario involves non-state actors constructing a rudimentary nuclear bomb using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). Both scenarios are highly challenging, and the likelihood of successfully stealing and detonating an actual nuclear weapon or creating an improvised device by non-state actors is considered low. However, this likelihood is not zero.
Will a nuclear explosion by a non-state actor result in at least one death by 2030?
This question will be resolved as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear explosion by a non-state actor causes at least one death anywhere in the world.
The death must be caused by the immediate effects of the explosion, so deaths caused by fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be sourced from reliable news outlets or direct government or multinational reports, such as those from the UN.
Detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions will not count towards question resolution, even if they cause significant damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as those claimed to be tests or peaceful nuclear explosions by an official government statement within 30 days of the event, without dispute from reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, the resolution will be determined by the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

para_P.title: Will a nuclear detonation by a non-state entity lead to at least one fatality by the year 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation executed by a non-state entity could lead to dire outcomes, either directly or by instigating additional detrimental actions. Although non-state entities have never set off nuclear arms, there are credible scenarios where they could:
Most experts in nuclear security emphasize two primary scenarios involving nuclear arms and non-state entities. The first scenario entails terrorists or other non-state groups acquiring a nuclear device from the arsenals of nuclear-capable nations. The second scenario involves non-state groups fabricating a basic nuclear bomb utilizing special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). Both scenarios present significant challenges, and the probability of successfully stealing and detonating an actual nuclear weapon or producing an improvised device by non-state actors is deemed low. Nonetheless, this probability is not zero.
Will a nuclear detonation by a non-state entity lead to at least one fatality by the year 2030?
This question will be answered with a Yes if, prior to January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state entity results in at least one fatality anywhere globally.
The fatality must be due to the immediate consequences of the explosion, thus fatalities resulting from fallout, civil unrest, or climatic impacts will not be considered for a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be drawn from trustworthy news sources or direct governmental or multinational reports, such as those from the UN.
Detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions will not be counted towards the resolution of the question, even if they cause substantial damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are characterized as those declared to be tests or peaceful nuclear detonations by an official government announcement within 30 days of the occurrence, without contradiction from credible media, state reports, or multinational reports. If the information is ambiguous, the resolution will be determined by the resolution council or Metaculus administrators.

P.title: In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The size of the US's nuclear weapons stockpile reached a peak in 1966 at around 30,000 warheads. Following the deescalation and the end of the Cold War, the number has substantially decreased. Kristensen and Korda (2019) estimate that the US maintains a deployed stockpile of nearly 3,800 warheads. The approximate breakdown is as follows:
1,750 warheads are currently deployed, of which
1,300 strategic warheads are deployed on ballistic missiles,
300 at strategic bomber bases in the United States,
150 tactical bombs are deployed at air bases in Europe.
2,050 are in storage as a so-called hedge against technical or geopolitical surprises.
It is possible that this trend will reverse in a period of nuclear rearmament, especially if world tensions get worse. The Trump Administration’s Nuclear Posture Review takes a confrontational tone, presenting an assertive posture that embraces “Great Power competition” and includes plans to expand the US' nuclear arsenal.
In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
This resolves positive if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (such as this one for 2019) reports that the US held 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any time in 2029. A similar credible source may be consulted if the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists in no longer active or publishing reports. For the purposes of question resolution, warheads that are retired and awaiting dismantlement will not be counted.
See also the related question, If the US does not pursue nuclear disarmament, how many nuclear warheads will it have in 2029?

Criteria for Resolution

Since then, following the reduction of tensions and the conclusion of the Cold War, this number has significantly declined. 1,750 warheads actively deployed, comprised of
1,300 strategic warheads positioned on ballistic missiles,

The Nuclear Posture Review under the Trump Administration adopts a confrontational stance, advocating for a proactive approach that acknowledges "Great Power competition" and includes intentions to expand the US nuclear capabilities.
By the year 2029, will the United States have 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads?

For the resolution of this question, warheads that have been retired and are pending dismantlement will not be included in the count.

P.title: Will the WTA and ATP merge before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both men and women play as part of one tour with one tour organiser in top competitive Tennis. It will also resolve as Yes if not all tournaments are mixed (ie if some currently all-female or all-male tournaments are part of the tour, that doesn't trigger negative resolution as long as the overarching tour organiser is one body)
This question will resolve as No if men and women play as part of two separate tours on the basis of gender.
In the event that it is unclear (eg the tennis tour fractures into multiple tours (WTA, ATP, mixed tour)) we will ask Jeff Sackmann's opinion and resolve at his discretion. (In the event he says it's unclear / is uncontactable / unwilling to decide, the question will resolve as Ambiguous

This question will be answered negatively if male and female players continue to participate in distinct tours based on gender.
Should there be any ambiguity (for example, if the tennis tour splits into several tours such as WTA, ATP, and a mixed tour), we will seek the opinion of Jeff Sackmann and resolve based on his judgment. If he deems it unclear or is unavailable/unwilling to provide a decision, the question will be classified as Ambiguous.

P.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since October 31 2000, the date Soyuz TM-31 lifted off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome carrying the members of Expedition 1, the first long-duration ISS crew, humanity has maintained a permanent off-Earth presence for more than 19 years.
This question asks: Will humanity maintain an off-Earth presence continuously until 1 January 2050?
For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers / settlers).
If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

P.title: Will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey is a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025. The question will resolve as No if Turkey is suspended or expelled from NATO, or if it withdraws of its own accord, at any time before January 1, 2025.
If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous

P.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Kamala Harris)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.

P.title: Will any top 10 global meat processor/producer go bankrupt before 2028?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Cargill, Tyson Foods, Hormel, Muyuan Foods, Wens Foodstuff Group, or any of their parent companies file for bankruptcy by January 1, 2028, according to credible financial media reports.
This question will resolve positively if Cargill, Tyson Foods or Hormel (or any of their parent companies) submits a court filing seeking bankruptcy protection under any provision of the United States Bankruptcy Code, or if Muyuan Foods or Wens Foodstuff Group (or any of their parent companies) apply for bankruptcy proceedings in China. It will also resolve positively if Kerry Group applies for bankruptcy proceedings in Ireland, JBS in Brazil, the WH Group in Hong Kong, Mowi ASA in Norway, or the Marubeni Corporation in Japan.
Positive resolution requires a filing only. No court ruling needs to be made.
If any of the relevant companies are acquired or merged, and the new entity files for bankruptcy within two years of the acquisition or merger, the question will resolve positively
